results.title: The Lost wax method of bronze casting
results.creator_credit: Fotosonic, Harmon Foundation and Leo Steiner
results.brief_description: Vincent Kofi, a Ghanian sculptor, is shown making a bronze casting of his “Awakening Africa” using the lost wax method. The process - from modelling the original clay figurine to the finished work on the metal casting - is shown.

results.title: The Lost waters of the Nile
results.creator_credit: Alec Nisbett, KRO-TV Hilversum and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Report on the issues surrounding the construction of the Jonglei Canal, a massive engineering project intended to bypass an enormous area of marshland formed by the waters of the White Nile. Considers in particular the effects on the Dinka people who inhabit the area and the difficulties facing the builders of the canal.

results.title: The Lost tribe
results.creator_credit: Meridian Films, New Zealand Film Commission, Gary Hannam and John Laing
results.brief_description: In this suspense thriller, a missing anthropologist is given up for lost by his wife (Darien Takle) and twin brother Edward (John Bach), but his daughter (Emma Takle) is convinced something odd is involved in her father’s disappearance. Events conspire to put the three people together on a manhunt for the anthropologist amongst a “lost” tribe in the dense jungle of the southern island of New Zealand.

results.title: The Lost pharaoh: the search for Akhenaten
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly and Nicholas Kendall
results.brief_description: The fascinating story of an ancient Pharaoh and the archaeological sleuthing which went into piecing together information about his life. An accidental discovery in 1975 by Canadian archaeologist Dr. Donald Redford and his team led to the uncovering of the foundation of one of Akhenaten’s temples. Commentary and narration by Donald Brittain.

results.title: The Lost James Brown tapes
results.creator_credit: Gravity, Chris Mould and Alan Douglas
results.brief_description: Exciting live concert footage of the master of funk and godfather of soul, the inimitable James Brown. Supposedly shot in Monterey, California in 1979, this live concert shows the master in fine form. His powerful voice and trademark dance moves don’t disappoint but the transition to DVD format is a little dubious (may have been shot off a television screen). The ten songs featured are: “Get up offa that thing”, “Body heat”, “Try me”, “Sex machine”, “Georgia on my mind”, “Please please please”, “Hindsight”, “Can’t stand it”, “Papa’s got a brand new bag” and “Jam”. Original producers of the live concert footage were Eric Therman, Rod Crowe and Robert Sheridan. The title listed on the cover (as opposed to the actual work) is “James Brown: Body Heat Live”.

results.title: The Lost generation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Work that was”.
Keith Windschuttle, looks at the problems of high youth unemployment as manifested in the increasing numbers of young homeless people squatting in derelict houses. Suggests that more innovations in secondary education would help prepare students for the realities of the present job market.

results.title: The Lost babies
results.brief_description: A documentary about the tragedy of babies who are either stillborn or who die very soon after birth and the emotional consequences for the parents. Parents who have experienced the death of their baby discuss their reactions and specialists talk about how they can help the parents through the grieving process.

results.title: The Lord of the rings: the two towers special extended edition [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Wingnut Films, Peter Jackson, Barrie M Osborne and Fran Walsh
results.brief_description: The fight between good and evil is played out using spectacular locations and stupendous special effects in “The Two Towers”, the second instalment of Peter Jackson’s iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings”. Middle Earth is now on the brink of a vicious war, and its fate rests on the shoulders of the ‘Fellowship’, now separated into three groups. Pulled by the ring’s power, Frodo heads towards Mount Doom with Sam, only to encounter an unlikely guide; Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli head towards Rohan; and Merry and Pippin find an ally in the terrifying Fangorn Forest. While this film culminates in two spectacular battles between the humans of Helm’s Deep and Saruman’s vicious minions and Saruman and the Ents, the tale twists and turns around numerous subplots and many new characters, including the twisted half-hobbit Gollum, a warped creature who will do anything to regain what he believes is rightfully his. Once again, Jackson and his screenwriters successfully reproduce a classic tale, which, unlike a number of blockbuster sequels, equals if not surpasses its predecessor, both enthralling and teasing the audience as the tale continues. Cast includes Elijah Wood, Sean Astin, Dominic Monaghan, Billy Boyd, John Rhys-Davies, Viggo Mortensen, Orlando Bloom, Christopher Lee, Ian McKellen, Liv Tyler, Hugo Weaving, Brad Dourif, Miranda Otto, Karl Urban, Bernard Hill, David Wenham and Andy Serkis as the voice of Gollum.

results.title: The Lord of the rings: the return of the king
results.creator_credit: Wingnut Films, New Line Cinema, Barrie M Osborne, Fran Walsh and Peter Jackson
results.brief_description: Final part of Peter Jacksons iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings” trilogy sees the interleaved narrative threads of parts one and two drawn to closure. As per the other instalments (filmed simultaneously), Jackson goes to meticulous lengths to bring Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen by building extensive sets in his native New Zealand and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. Still divided, the fellowship continue their separate quests; Frodo and Sam head towards Mount Doom led by the duplicitous Gollum; Aragon, Legolas and Gimli fight numerous battles and engage the services of a ghost army; Merry and Pippin drift in and out of trouble. With unrivalled flourish, Jackson invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, with his awesome CGI wizardry and stupendous set pieces. But whilst the ambitious battle scenes are masterful, the film lacks satisfying arcs (as part 3, perhaps by necessity, its all climaxes) and is let down by an interminable ending. Nevertheless Jackson creates a grand spectacle, setting superior standards for the capturing of epic grandeur and he garnered eleven Academy Awards (2004) including Best director.

results.description: Final part of Peter Jacksons iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings” trilogy sees the interleaved narrative threads of parts one and two drawn to closure. As per the other instalments (filmed simultaneously), Jackson goes to meticulous lengths to bring Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen by building extensive sets in his native New Zealand and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. Still divided, the fellowship continue their separate quests; Frodo and Sam head towards Mount Doom led by the duplicitous Gollum; Aragon, Legolas and Gimli fight numerous battles and engage the services of a ghost army; Merry and Pippin drift in and out of trouble. With unrivalled flourish, Jackson invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, with his awesome CGI wizardry and stupendous set pieces. But whilst the ambitious battle scenes are masterful, the film lacks satisfying arcs (as part 3, perhaps by necessity, its all climaxes) and is let down by an interminable ending. Nevertheless Jackson creates a grand spectacle, setting superior standards for the capturing of epic grandeur and he garnered eleven Academy Awards (2004) including Best director.

results.title: The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings (Special extended edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Wingnut Films, New Line Cinema, Tim Sanders, Fran Walsh and Peter Jackson
results.brief_description: Iconic adaptation of J R R Tolkien’s fantasy epic, “The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the rings” is the first instalment of the “Rings” trilogy. Director Peter Jackson (Heavenly creatures, The Frighteners, Meet the Feebles) went to incredible lengths to re-create Tolkien’s fantastical vision to the screen by building extensive sets in his native New Zealand and by employing a slew of gifted special effects artists. In short, Frodo Baggins, a kind-hearted and earnest hobbit, is entrusted with the gallant mission to return a powerful ring from whence it came - Mount Doom, the only place where it can be destroyed. Failure to do so will result in the destruction of the earth, as the powerful ring is capable of unleashing inestimable evil. Guided by Gandalf, a powerful wizard, Frodo is accompanied on his treacherous journey by three hobbit friends, a dwarf, an elf and several humans. This heroic quest invokes all the necessary thrills of an adventure picture, whilst satiating the exacting standards of an audience inured to CGI wizardry, and gratifying legions of zealous Tolkien fans. With ambitious battle scenes and stupendous set pieces, this grand and masterful cinematic spectacle kept most viewers utterly enthralled, whilst earning Jackson almost universal praise for capturing Tolkien’s mythopoeic narrative and elegiac tone.
